results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15     Suicide Bombing Claims 4 Victims in Jerusalem   Three suicide bombers set off explosions on a popular pedestrian thoroughfare in Jerusalem, killing four passers-by and wounding about 180 others. The bombers apparently acted...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Suicide Bombing Claims 4 Victims in Jerusalem Three suicide bombers set off explosions on a popular pedestrian thoroughfare in Jerusalem, killing four passers-by and wounding about 180 others. The bombers apparently acted in concert. An offshoot of the Islamic fundamentalist Hamas movement claimed responsibility. A1 President Clinton condemned the bombings in Jerusalem and said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright would visit the Middle East next week as planned. A15

results.abstract: Russian astronaut Anatoly Solovyev and American counterpart, Michael Foale, begin complex and potentially hazardous space walk to help restore problem-plagued Mir space station; will search for hole resulting from June 25 collision with unmanned cargo craft and undertake other repairs; photo; diagram (M)

headline.main: Russian and American Astronauts Begin Space Walk

results.snippet: Russian and American astronauts clambered out of the star-crossed Mir this morning and began a complex and potentially hazardous space walk to help restore the space station.    Clad in a Russian-made spacesuit, the American astronaut Michael Foale...
results.lead_paragraph: Russian and American astronauts clambered out of the star-crossed Mir this morning and began a complex and potentially hazardous space walk to help restore the space station. Clad in a Russian-made spacesuit, the American astronaut Michael Foale was the first to venture through the hatch. He was followed by Anatoly Solovyev, the Mir commander.

results.abstract: Six-hour space walk by Russian and US astronauts Anatoly Solovyev and Michael Foale fails to locate hole in damaged Mir space station; complicated and risky spacewalk had been billed as reconnaissance mission to find a hole or holes punched into Mir during collision with space cargo vessel on June 25; collision damaged Spektr module, which was used for scientific research, forcing crew to seal off section and curtailing its power supply; photo (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Fail to Locate A Puncture Crippling Mir

results.snippet: A six-hour spacewalk by Russian and American astronauts this morning was unable to locate the hole in the damaged Mir, dealing a major setback to efforts to repair the stricken space station.    The complicated and risky spacewalk had been billed as...
results.lead_paragraph: A six-hour spacewalk by Russian and American astronauts this morning was unable to locate the hole in the damaged Mir, dealing a major setback to efforts to repair the stricken space station. The complicated and risky spacewalk had been billed as a reconnaissance mission to find a hole or holes punched into Mir during a collision with a space cargo vessel on June 25.

results.abstract: Correction of September 6 article on spacewalk from Mir space station
results.snippet: An article on Saturday about a spacewalk from the Mir space station misidentified a Russian astronaut. He is Anatoly Solovyov, not Vladimir Solovyov, no relation, who is a Russian space official.
results.lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about a spacewalk from the Mir space station misidentified a Russian astronaut. He is Anatoly Solovyov, not Vladimir Solovyov, no relation, who is a Russian space official.

results.abstract: Computer on Russian space station Mir fails for third time since mid-July, forcing crew to shut down most of equipment; Russian and American space officials play down seriousness of computer crash; station is able to maintain its orientation toward Sun, and its power supplies are in much better shape than during previous breakdowns (M)

headline.main: Computer on Mir Fails, Forcing Crew to Shut Down Equipment

results.snippet: The Mir's computer broke down again today and forced the crew to shut down most of the space station's equipment.    Russian and American space officials played down the seriousness of the computer crash, the third aboard Mir since mid-July. The...
results.lead_paragraph: The Mir's computer broke down again today and forced the crew to shut down most of the space station's equipment. Russian and American space officials played down the seriousness of the computer crash, the third aboard Mir since mid-July. The station was able to maintain its orientation toward the Sun, and its power supplies were in much better shape than during the previous breakdowns.

results.abstract: Article on Sounds Like Science, offbeat science program hosted by Ira Flatow and broadcast over WSHU-FM in Connecticut and other National Public Radio affiliates across US; photo (M)
results.snippet: EACH Thursday evening, a  man leans toward a microphone in a spare studio at WSHU-FM in Fairfield and enthusiastically says, ''Hi, I'm Ira Flatow, and this is 'Sounds Like Science.' '' Actually, he says it several times, piped from Connecticut to a...
results.section_name: Technology; Science; New York and Region
results.lead_paragraph: EACH Thursday evening, a man leans toward a microphone in a spare studio at WSHU-FM in Fairfield and enthusiastically says, ''Hi, I'm Ira Flatow, and this is 'Sounds Like Science.' '' Actually, he says it several times, piped from Connecticut to a National Public Radio recording studio in Washington, D.C., where his producer and her engineers patch the program together from bits and pieces. When ''Sounds Like Science'' is broadcast each Saturday afternoon (at 4 P.M. on WSHU and other NPR affiliates), none of the seams are evident. Instead, listeners might share Mr. Flatow's conviction that science is entertaining and fun. He believes that people want more news about science, and he wants to produce it from Connecticut.

results.abstract: James C Adamson, chief operating officer of United Space Alliance, which runs space shuttles for NASA, discusses possible use of shuttles to salvage orbiting satellites that have run out of fuel; is optimistic about commercialization of shuttle program and outlook for complete privatization; photo; diagrams (L)

headline.main: New Work Proposed For Shuttles: Salvage in Space

results.snippet: BILLIONS of dollars' worth of old communication, weather and spy satellites are circling Earth, dead or dormant and usually adrift. Typically, there is little or nothing wrong with them. They have just run out of fuel.    Space-age garbage?    Not to...
results.lead_paragraph: BILLIONS of dollars' worth of old communication, weather and spy satellites are circling Earth, dead or dormant and usually adrift. Typically, there is little or nothing wrong with them. They have just run out of fuel. Space-age garbage? Not to James C. Adamson, a former astronaut who is the chief operating officer of the United Space Alliance, the company that NASA has put in charge of running the space shuttles.

results.abstract: Russian space station Mir came within 500 to 1,000 yards of colliding with United States military satellite, forcing crew, which is struggling to fix central computer, into Soyuz re-entry capsule to prepare for fast getaway if needed; Mir survived without damage; NASA and Russian space officials brush off encounter as minor incident (M)

headline.main: Satellite Gives Mir One More Close Call

results.snippet: Even as crew members struggled to fix their central computer, the Russian space station Mir came within 500 to 1,000 yards of colliding with a United States military satellite on Monday night.     The Mir survived without any damage. But the...
results.lead_paragraph: Even as crew members struggled to fix their central computer, the Russian space station Mir came within 500 to 1,000 yards of colliding with a United States military satellite on Monday night. The Mir survived without any damage. But the satellite came close enough that the three crew members, including the American astronaut Michael Foale, sealed themselves into the Soyuz re-entry capsule to make a fast getaway in case the space station was going to get hit.

results.abstract: NASA officials, in testimony before House Science Committee, say it is safe to send Americans to live aboard troubled Mir space station, but committee members say further stays aboard Russian craft pose unacceptable risks (S)

headline.main: NASA Aides and House Panel Debate Safety of Mir Station

results.snippet: As NASA officials testified that it was safe to send more Americans to live on the troubled Mir space station, members of the House Science Committee said today that further stays aboard the Russian craft posed unacceptable risks.    ''There has been...
results.lead_paragraph: As NASA officials testified that it was safe to send more Americans to live on the troubled Mir space station, members of the House Science Committee said today that further stays aboard the Russian craft posed unacceptable risks. ''There has been sufficient evidence put before this hearing to raise doubts about the safety of continued American long-term presence on the Mir,'' said Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, the committee chairman.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis takes off for rendezvous with Mir space station after NASA Admr Daniel S Goldin decides that Dr David A Wolf can replace US astronaut C Michael Foale for extended stay aboard Russian craft; photo (M)

headline.main: U.S. Doctor on Shuttle to Join 2 Russians

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis took off tonight for a rendezvous with the Mir space station after the NASA Administrator decided that Dr. David A. Wolf could replace another American astronaut for an extended stay aboard the Russian craft.    Dr. Wolf, a...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis took off tonight for a rendezvous with the Mir space station after the NASA Administrator decided that Dr. David A. Wolf could replace another American astronaut for an extended stay aboard the Russian craft. Dr. Wolf, a 41-year-old physician, and six other astronauts blasted off in Atlantis at 10:34 P.M. Eastern time on a 10-day mission to dock with Mir. After a planned linkup on Saturday, Dr. Wolf is supposed to change places with C. Michael Foale and begin a four-month stay aboard the Russian station.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-13    Canadians Feeling Bruised By Relations With America  Canadians are feeling bruised and bewildered by their ally to the south. Tough new restrictions for crossing the border have upset them. Trade conflicts over milk and...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Canadians Feeling Bruised By Relations With America Canadians are feeling bruised and bewildered by their ally to the south. Tough new restrictions for crossing the border have upset them. Trade conflicts over milk and magazines have rattled Ottawa. And Canadians are profoundly disappointed by the failure of the United States to sign the anti-land-mine treaty, a Canadian-led move viewed as a national accomplishment. On top of all that is a deepening conflict over Pacific salmon. ''What's going on here?'' asked The Globe and Mail. A1

results.abstract: Brief descriptions of several 'firsts' for Long Island, NY: first trans-Atlantic flight (Charles Lindbergh), first significant poet (Walt Whitman), first golf course (Shinnecock Hills), first cattle ranch (Montauk) first lighthouse (Moutauk Point), first moon craft (Apollo 11), first supermarket (King Kullen) and first modern parkway (Vanderbilt Motor Parkway); photos (M)
results.snippet: First Trans-Atlantic Flight     Charles A. Lindbergh was no fan of the popular press that made him internationally famous.
results.lead_paragraph: First Trans-Atlantic Flight Charles A. Lindbergh was no fan of the popular press that made him internationally famous.
